citation.article-title: Thermococcus peptonophilus sp. nov., a fast-growing, extremely thermophilic archaebacterium isolated from deep-sea hydrothermal vents.

p.s: Description of Thermococcus peptonophilus sp. nov.
Thermococcus peptonophilus (pep.to.no'.phi.lus Gr. adj. peptos cooked; Gr. adj. philos loving; M.L. adj. peptonophilus peptone-loving, indicating that it grows only on peptides as carbon source)
Cells are cocci, 0.7-2 μm in diameter, occurring mostly singly or in pairs.
Motile with a polar tuft of flagella.
The cell envelope consists of two layers, the external one is electron-dense.
Temperature range of growth from 60 to 100°C optimum 85°C pH range of growth from pH 3 to 8, with the optimum around pH 6.
NaCl concentrations allowing growth range from 1 to 5%; optimum 3%.
Sulfur is not essential for growth, although elemental sulfur greatly stimulates growth.
Heterotrophic growth on peptone, tryptone, yeast extract, beef extract and/or non-hydrolyzed casein.
No growth on free amino acids, sugars, organic acids, or in the absence of organic substrates.
16S rRNA gene sequence is deposited at the GSDB, DDBJ, EMBL, and NLBI nucleotide sequence databases under the accession number D37982.
Inhabits marine hydrothermal vents in the western Pacific Ocean, specifically found in Izu-Bonin and South Mariana Trough areas.
Type strain: Thermococcus peptonophilus OG-1, JCM 9653, Wako-shi, Japan.
